description: An essence-mutated cattail, known as a bangtail.  The rhizome is hallucinogenic and often smoked once dried and rolled into a joint or cigarette.
An essence-mutated cattail, known as a bangtail. The stalk and bud is used to make a form of smokeless gunpowder.

Mireweeds are a wetland plant which collects fresh water in a large fruit.  Nobody is sure why it's named a weed, it can grow anywhere in brackish water and saps the nutrients to make a strong stimulant.  It was likely named by smugglers trying to grow storm ferns, frustrated at their failed drug harvests.
Brineweeds grow deep in the Great Swamps and other corrupted marshlands, they are a concentrated coagulant and lessen the effects of the flu.

This swamp weed was thought to have been native to Lunar Valley until Dwellers foraged it to extinction.  It has anesthetic properties when refined, if used raw it is reportedly similar to nitrous oxide and was used for religious practices.  Whether one can reach spiritual enlightenment from plants is still to be determined.
A disgusting wetland plant which coagulates into a jelly when fried and is commonly used as a disinfectant or painkiller.
Sometimes mistaken for swamp fish as one likely evolved to appear as the other, it is known to kill fungi and if ingested makes a user sleepy.

The pride of the Great Swamps, this typical fern requires care to cultivate.  While its leaves are anti-psychotic and the roots hold a stimulant property, with proper chemical reaction and other extracts it creates the most addictive drug known to humanity.

A common root that grows in the mud of the Great Swamps.  Historically the bane of Imperial and Rotter biological warfare, it is a powerful antibiotic that led to an overabundance of medicine in rebel-controlled lands.
A brownish-orange root known to grow in most regions, it can expel radioactive particles from the body and acts as a painkiller.
This dangerous and highly illegal root is historically used for the production of explosives or hallucinogenic drugs.  Though it prefers arid climates and sandy soil, it will readily grow anywhere.
Scientists are unsure what advantage the grass gained when it became red, it is used as a coagulant and mild stimulant.  Mages will note it is used as a substitute for human blood.

This grass turned bright orange and became a powerful stimulant.  It contains a hallucinogenic compound that is not normally observed in unrefined usage, the stimulant chemical is also used in explosives manufacturing either separately or with gravebane shrubs.
A white grass found in areas of death, it purges parasites on consumption and a sedative is extracted from large amounts of it.
Resembling the yellow fibers of an old-fashioned broom, it is known to contain small traces of disinfectants and coagulants.  They are a valuable source of durable fibers for mages

These bone white flowers are known to sprout on corpses where they continue to spread, their roots are antibiotic and their petals are a mild painkiller.  Not considered very useful given the trace quantities of chemicals, it may hold anomalous healing properties which have never been officially investigated.

A white moss which covers and overtakes corpses, it contains small amounts of antibiotics and coagulants which is used for wound dressings.  It is an important industry for many communities to cultivate it via prisoner execution.  It is also a weed that grows around other plants associated with death.
A solid white thistle which grows near sites of mass death, known to aid insomnia.  In large quantities it will cause hallucinations and madness.  It may also collect the power of the dead.
A solid white bush which grows near corpses and inside graveyards, it is another source of anesthetic but is well-known for it's usage as explosives when combined with stim grass.
Though it may look like a lemon, these fruits contain taroline and are thus a naturally-occuring combustible fuel that very angry individuals have used to burn homes and military equipment with.

Sour, green berries off a bush growing in the wasteland. It's not quite right, but it doesn't spoil that fast.  You could extract seeds, if you really wanted. They grow in the harsh soil and surprisingly survive underground.

Naturally high in sodium, these nuts leech salts from the waste soil and are non-perishable like peanuts. Edible raw, it will dehydrate you and is incredibly unpleasant. You should boil away their salt content.  You could extract seeds, if you really wanted. They grow in the harsh soil
You boiled the salt away, making it more suitable for consumption and some cooking recipes that don't want salt.

An ugly and rough wasteland potato that appears sickly on the inside. A great source of vitamins when cooked, but disgusting to eat raw. It can't spoil when raw, it's too anomalous... and plain wrong. Baking it changes the flavor and color, but will allow it to spoil.  You could extract seeds, if you really wanted. They grow in the harsh soil and underground.
A bland but satisfying potato that was cooked. Could use butter if such a thing still existed. It's not an odd color anymore.
A long chunk of wood from a sapling or bush that grows in the miserable climate. Though the same volume it is slightly denser which can have useful properties.
A chunk of wood from an anomalous sapling. It is abnormally lightweight and soft, making it not usable as wood. It's flammable but it is more useful for magical applications.
A dense pod of seeds and cotton, you can process it to get desert cotton seeds and cotton balls.
A pad from a cactus in the wasteland, filled with water and a few calories. You need to squeeze it to get the water out, eating will waste most of it.
A pad from a cactus in the wasteland, squeezed dry. Now it's only good as a snack.
A fruit from a waste cactus. It'll make you high if you eat it. Containing a similiar composition to bangtail powder, this can be ground as a substitue with the juice discarded.

use_action.activation_message: You eat some cactus fruit. Yeaaaah dude.

description: Pale white cave beans, naturally growing underground. You can cultivate these year-round and they dry out on their own. High in protein, low in misery if cooked.
A serving of white cave beans, high in protein and rich in vitamins, now you need fruit.
